question.title: Spring MVC static resource location and mapping

node.contents: Hi Evgeny, please show us what the error messages you're getting are when you try to go to http://localhost:8080/css/style.css in your browser, as well as what stacktraces you see in the logs. NOTE **localhost:8080 in the address bar should be replaced with whatever servername you use to access your project, if that's not already clear.** Also, it would help to see the servlet configuration from web.xml. Use the [edit] link to edit your question with these details.

astNode.text: Hi Evgeny, please show us what the error messages you're getting are when you try to go to http://localhost:8080/css/style.css in your browser, as well as what stacktraces you see in the logs. NOTE **localhost:8080 in the address bar should be replaced with whatever servername you use to access your project, if that's not already clear.** Also, it would help to see the servlet configuration from web.xml. node.contents: Hi, thanks for the response. http://localhost:8081/table/css/style.css shows me the content of the css file. Chrome's development tools tells me: "GET http://localhost:8081/css/style.css 404(Not found)"(No my project name here...), in the jsp.

astNode.text: Hi, thanks for the response. http://localhost:8081/table/css/style.css shows me the content of the css file. Chrome's development tools tells me: "GET http://localhost:8081/css/style.css 404(Not found)"(No my project name here...), in the jsp.

node.contents: So table is your project name?

astNode.text: So table is your project name?

node.contents: yes(test project)

node.contents:
So if you change `
<link href="/css/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />` to `
<link href="/table/css/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />` does it work? Context paths off of localhost always were confusing... Java drops "table" from the uri patterns, but the browser sees it as part of the path...

astNode.text:
So if you change `
<link href="/css/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />` to `
<link href="/table/css/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />` does it work? Context paths off of localhost always were confusing... Java drops "table" from the uri patterns, but the browser sees it as part of the path...

node.contents: Yes, thanks. Best regards.

astNode.text: Yes, thanks. Best regards.

node.contents: Hi gigadot, I'm out of votes, but you'll definitely get my +1 later. I think the best approach is to use both the base tag in combination with the c:url tag. OP still gets the benefits you mention if the context path changes, but only has to change just the base element instead of every single link on the project. Great answer :)

astNode.text: Hi gigadot, I'm out of votes, but you'll definitely get my +1 later. I think the best approach is to use both the base tag in combination with the c:url tag. OP still gets the benefits you mention if the context path changes, but only has to change just the base element instead of every single link on the project. Great answer :)

node.contents: Thank you @jmort253, you are right.

astNode.text: Thank you @jmort253, you are right.

node.contents: Using JSTL c tag to solve the context path problem:

astNode.text: Using JSTL c tag to solve the context path problem:

node.contents: which will give you:

astNode.text: which will give you:

node.contents: This tag is recommended and you should wrap all your urls with it since the JSLT processor will generate the correct context path for you even if you decide to change the context path later without having to go through every single link in all jsp files.

astNode.text: This tag is recommended and you should wrap all your urls with it since the JSLT processor will generate the correct context path for you even if you decide to change the context path later without having to go through every single link in all jsp files.

node.contents: Hi Evgeny, as an aside, if you combine gigadot's proposed solution with the base tag, then it will save you the trouble of needing to edit every single link on your site and cluttering the HTML, while still making the base tag be dynamic so that if you change the context path, it will still be reflected everywhere, but in a manner that doesn't bind you so tightly to the framework. :)

astNode.text: Hi Evgeny, as an aside, if you combine gigadot's proposed solution with the base tag, then it will save you the trouble of needing to edit every single link on your site and cluttering the HTML, while still making the base tag be dynamic so that if you change the context path, it will still be reflected everywhere, but in a manner that doesn't bind you so tightly to the framework. :)

node.contents: i don't think you want to have target="_blank". that will make all links to be opened in new windows, right?

astNode.text: i don't think you want to have target="_blank". that will make all links to be opened in new windows, right?

node.contents:
and i don't think it's `
<c:url value="/" />`, not `
<c:url value="/table" />`

node.contents: To solve this problem so that your code will run with the actual paths you would use in production, use a <base> tag in your JSP pages, like so:

astNode.text: To solve this problem so that your code will run with the actual paths you would use in production, use a <base> tag in your JSP pages, like so:

node.contents: This will ensure that all of the rest of the relative paths in your JSP page can be represented using the full paths:

astNode.text: This will ensure that all of the rest of the relative paths in your JSP page can be represented using the full paths:

node.contents: For further reading, here is a reference at the Mozilla Developer Center on the usage of the HTML base element. Additionally, this blog post may also be helpful in giving you a perspective on working with client-side code, especially if you work with Web designers who are not Java developers.

astNode.text: For further reading, here is a reference at the Mozilla Developer Center on the usage of the HTML base element. Additionally, this blog post may also be helpful in giving you a perspective on working with client-side code, especially if you work with Web designers who are not Java developers.

node.contents: NOTE: As an aside, if you combine @gigadot's proposed solution to use c:url tags with the base tag, then it will save you the trouble of needing to edit every single link on your site and cluttering the HTML, while still making the base tag be dynamic so that if you change the context path, it will still be reflected everywhere, but in a manner that doesn't bind you so tightly to the framework.

astNode.text: NOTE: As an aside, if you combine @gigadot's proposed solution to use c:url tags with the base tag, then it will save you the trouble of needing to edit every single link on your site and cluttering the HTML, while still making the base tag be dynamic so that if you change the context path, it will still be reflected everywhere, but in a manner that doesn't bind you so tightly to the framework.

node.contents: I'm linking to that answer so that the credit for using the <c:url tag goes to @gigadot, yet documenting it here so that others can benefit from the combined knowledge of using both together.

astNode.text: I'm linking to that answer so that the credit for using the <c:url tag goes to @gigadot, yet documenting it here so that others can benefit from the combined knowledge of using both together.
